transcripts.text: The last few days saw the gathering of G7, seven of the top countries' presidents and prime ministers getting together in France to talk about a lot of issues, including Brexit. It all started with the French President Macron, who repeated what he has been saying since June.  As the leaders met to discuss Brexit, obviously Boris Johnson came prepared to propose a complete change to Theresa May's deal, not only to be the backstop, but also the £39 billion Brexit bill.  But President Macron, just like what he said back in June, has said that the UK failing to pay the Brexit bill would amount to a sovereign debt default.  And you can guess what Boris Johnson did.  When asked if he had told EU leaders this week that he planned to withhold the money, Mr Johnson told Sky News that, I think what the entire European Union understands is that if it comes out without a deal, then the £39bn is no longer legally pledged.  As I've said many, many times, we will therefore on the 1st of November have the very substantial sums available from that £39 billion to spend on supporting our farmers and indeed for investment in all sorts of areas.  Now Boris' hard no when it comes to the £39bn didn't really go down with the EU fanatics.  The Irish politician Senator Richmond said that there is a massive lack of understanding in the UK on what the Brexit bill actually is.  It's not a punishment payment, It's a settling of accounts based on programs the UK has already benefited from, like CAP, Erasmus, Horizon 2020, and not to mention pensions for British citizens.  But also the deputy director of the pro-EU think tank British Influence criticised the Prime Minister for saying that the UK won't pay the divorce bill.
